content: I have enlisted into the Army National Guard, I am prior service and have been excepted into the OCS program, I start next week phase O, I have the option to select the unit I will be going too, Thus leaving me with the option of what Branch I get.
reply: I have enlisted into the Army National Guard, I am prior service and have been excepted into the OCS program, I start next week phase O, I have the option to select the unit I will be going too, Thus leaving me with the option of what Branch I get.
title: Officers branch jobs

content: An almost unanswerable question, since most officers have only one (possibly two) that they would be familiar with. Any other opinion would be just that: an opinion, formed by superficial exposure at best. A better question would be to ask what a given branch is like and what sort of options are available. Sullivan013
reply: An almost unanswerable question, since most officers have only one (possibly two) that they would be familiar with. Any other opinion would be just that: an opinion, formed by superficial exposure at best. A better question would be to ask what a given branch is like and what sort of options are available. Sullivan013
title: Officers branch jobs

content: You didn't mention what your education has been. Your education should determine what job you should chose. If you have a degree in engineering then go into the engineers. If you are trained to kill people then go infantry. etc. If you have no college then you are screwed, you may be a personnel officer or work in S-4 or something similar. Those are decent jobs but you are inside all the time doing paperwork.
reply: You didn't mention what your education has been. Your education should determine what job you should chose. If you have a degree in engineering then go into the engineers. If you are trained to kill people then go infantry. etc. If you have no college then you are screwed, you may be a personnel officer or work in S-4 or something similar. Those are decent jobs but you are inside all the time doing paperwork.
title: Officers branch jobs

content: Officers in tank regiments and recon squadrons are about as close as you can get to being a pilot without getting off the ground. They are usually Tank Commanders with their own vehicle and crew, but they are also in charge of Platoons (5 tanks) and Companies (15 tanks) with the tasking of using those vehicles, much the same as a squadron of bombers in the Air Force to attack and destroy the enemy - - Why Armor? I'm partial to riding instead of walking for hundreds of miles, with a 60 ton monster to carry all my stuff instead of the shoulder straps of my web gear and the soles of my feet - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Officers in tank regiments and recon squadrons are about as close as you can get to being a pilot without getting off the ground. content: I am a 13M MLRS Crew member, I am working at a BA in Applied Science, I have worked Emergency response, HAZMAT, and Safety (OSHA instructor)for 6 years in a large factory and in construction. I am a Soilder, Combat is not an issue for me.
reply: I am a 13M MLRS Crew member, I am working at a BA in Applied Science, I have worked Emergency response, HAZMAT, and Safety (OSHA instructor)for 6 years in a large factory and in construction. I am a Soilder, Combat is not an issue for me.
title: Officers branch jobs

content: GWG, The US Army went to a four tank platoon in the 80s with the J-series MTO&E (14 tank company - 3 platoons + 2 tanks for the CO and XO). blaine68, Surely there are officers in those units you can contact, even by phone? What are the options (in general terms, no need to be that specific)? If you want combat operations, you probably know the basics of Infantry, Armor or Artillery. Platoon leaders are Lieutenants, Battalion staff officers are higher ranking lieutenants and captains. Company/Battery commanders are senior captains and the top two Battalion officers (XO and S-3) are likely Majors. Adding in the schools you will attend, that's the first fifteen years of your career. It's pretty much the same in Infantry or Armor, only with different schools. Combat Support and Service Support are slightly different, with more positions in Brigade/Division/Corps staff after making Captain. Sullivan013
reply: GWG, The US Army went to a four tank platoon in the 80s with the J-series MTO&E (14 tank company - 3 platoons + 2 tanks for the CO and XO). blaine68, Surely there are officers in those units you can contact, even by phone? What are the options (in general terms, no need to be that specific)? If you want combat operations, you probably know the basics of Infantry, Armor or Artillery. Platoon leaders are Lieutenants, Battalion staff officers are higher ranking lieutenants and captains. Company/Battery commanders are senior captains and the top two Battalion officers (XO and S-3) are likely Majors. Adding in the schools you will attend, that's the first fifteen years of your career. It's pretty much the same in Infantry or Armor, only with different schools. Combat Support and Service Support are slightly different, with more positions in Brigade/Division/Corps staff after making Captain. Sullivan013

content: I am a 13M MLRS Crew member, I am working at a BA in Applied Science, I have worked Emergency response, HAZMAT, and Safety (OSHA instructor)for 6 years in a large factory and in construction. I am a Soilder, Combat is not an issue for me.
reply: I am a 13M MLRS Crew member, I am working at a BA in Applied Science, I have worked Emergency response, HAZMAT, and Safety (OSHA instructor)for 6 years in a large factory and in construction. I am a Soilder, Combat is not an issue for me.
title: Officers branch jobs

content: GWG, The US Army went to a four tank platoon in the 80s with the J-series MTO&E (14 tank company - 3 platoons + 2 tanks for the CO and XO). blaine68, Surely there are officers in those units you can contact, even by phone? What are the options (in general terms, no need to be that specific)? If you want combat operations, you probably know the basics of Infantry, Armor or Artillery. Platoon leaders are Lieutenants, Battalion staff officers are higher ranking lieutenants and captains. Company/Battery commanders are senior captains and the top two Battalion officers (XO and S-3) are likely Majors. Adding in the schools you will attend, that's the first fifteen years of your career. It's pretty much the same in Infantry or Armor, only with different schools. Combat Support and Service Support are slightly different, with more positions in Brigade/Division/Corps staff after making Captain. Sullivan013
reply: GWG, The US Army went to a four tank platoon in the 80s with the J-series MTO&E (14 tank company - 3 platoons + 2 tanks for the CO and XO). blaine68, Surely there are officers in those units you can contact, even by phone? What are the options (in general terms, no need to be that specific)? If you want combat operations, you probably know the basics of Infantry, Armor or Artillery. Platoon leaders are Lieutenants, Battalion staff officers are higher ranking lieutenants and captains. Company/Battery commanders are senior captains and the top two Battalion officers (XO and S-3) are likely Majors. Adding in the schools you will attend, that's the first fifteen years of your career. It's pretty much the same in Infantry or Armor, only with different schools. Combat Support and Service Support are slightly different, with more positions in Brigade/Division/Corps staff after making Captain. Sullivan013

content: An almost unanswerable question, since most officers have only one (possibly two) that they would be familiar with. Any other opinion would be just that: an opinion, formed by superficial exposure at best. A better question would be to ask what a given branch is like and what sort of options are available. Sullivan013
reply: An almost unanswerable question, since most officers have only one (possibly two) that they would be familiar with. Any other opinion would be just that: an opinion, formed by superficial exposure at best. A better question would be to ask what a given branch is like and what sort of options are available. title: Officers branch jobs

content: You didn't mention what your education has been. Your education should determine what job you should chose. If you have a degree in engineering then go into the engineers. If you are trained to kill people then go infantry. etc. If you have no college then you are screwed, you may be a personnel officer or work in S-4 or something similar. Those are decent jobs but you are inside all the time doing paperwork.
reply: You didn't mention what your education has been. Your education should determine what job you should chose. If you have a degree in engineering then go into the engineers. If you are trained to kill people then go infantry. etc. If you have no college then you are screwed, you may be a personnel officer or work in S-4 or something similar. Those are decent jobs but you are inside all the time doing paperwork.
title: Officers branch jobs

content: Officers in tank regiments and recon squadrons are about as close as you can get to being a pilot without getting off the ground. They are usually Tank Commanders with their own vehicle and crew, but they are also in charge of Platoons (5 tanks) and Companies (15 tanks) with the tasking of using those vehicles, much the same as a squadron of bombers in the Air Force to attack and destroy the enemy - - Why Armor? I'm partial to riding instead of walking for hundreds of miles, with a 60 ton monster to carry all my stuff instead of the shoulder straps of my web gear and the soles of my feet - - Wandering and Wondering
reply: Officers in tank regiments and recon squadrons are about as close as you can get to being a pilot without getting off the ground.
